{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox artist | name = Abram Games | birth_date = {{birth date|1914|7|29|df=y}} | birth_place = Whitechapel, London | death_date = {{death date and age|1996|8|27|1914|7|29|df=y}} | death_place = London | spouse = {{marriage|Marianne Salfeld (1919–1988)|1945}} | nationality = British | field = Graphic design | training = [[Saint Martin's School of Art]] | website = {{Official website|http://www.abramgames.com/bb.htm}} }}
'''Abram Games''' {{Post-nominals|post-noms=[[Order of the British Empire|OBE]], [[Royal Designers for Industry|RDI]]}} (29 July 1914 in [[Whitechapel]], London – 27 August 1996 in London) was a British [[graphic designer]]. The style of his work – refined but vigorous compared to the work of contemporaries – has earned him a place in the pantheon of the best of 20th-century graphic designers. In acknowledging his power as a propagandist, he claimed, "I wind the spring and the public, in looking at the poster, will have that spring released in its mind." Because of the length of his career – over six decades – his work is essentially a record of the era's social history. Some of Britain's most iconic images include those by Games. An example is the "Join the ATS" poster of 1941, nicknamed the "blonde bombshell" recruitment poster. His work is recognised for its "striking colour, bold graphic ideas, and beautifully integrated typography".<ref name="Souter, Nick and Tessa 2012 203">{{cite book|last=Souter, Nick and Tessa|title=The Illustration Handbook: A Guide to the World's Greatest Illustrators|year=2012|publisher=Oceana|isbn=978-1-84573-473-2|pages=203}}</ref>
==Early life and career== Born '''Abraham Gamse''' in Whitechapel, London on 29 July, the day after [[World War I]] began in 1914, he was the son of Joseph Gamse, a [[Latvians|Latvian]] photographer, and Sarah, ''nee'' Rosenberg, a [[seamstress]] born on the border of Russia and Poland. His father, who had emigrated to Britain in 1904, anglicised the family name to Games when Abram was 12.<ref name="design">{{cite web | url=http://www.designmuseum.org/design/abram-games | title=Abram Games | publisher=[[Design Museum]] | date=2003 | accessdate=14 November 2014}}</ref> Games left [[Hackney Downs School]] at the age of 16 and, in 1930, went to [[Saint Martin's School of Art]] in London. Disillusioned by the teaching at Saint Martin's and worried about the expense of studying there, Games left after two terms.<ref name="RSlocombe">{{cite book|author=Richard Slocombe|publisher=Imperial War Museum|year=2014|title=British Posters of the Second World War |ISBN=978-1-904897-92-7}}</ref> However, Games was determined to establish himself as a poster artist so while working as a "studio boy" for the commercial design firm [[Askew-Young]] in London between 1932 and 1936, he attended night classes in life drawing. He was fired from this position due to his jumping over four chairs as a prank.<ref name=design/> In 1934, his entry was second in the [[Health Council Competition]] and, in 1935, won a poster competition for the [[London County Council]].<ref name=UOBag>{{cite web |author=|url=http://arts.brighton.ac.uk/collections/design-archives/resources/rdis-at-britain-can-make-it,-1946/abram-games |title=Abram Games|date= |accessdate=7 November 2016|work=University of Brighton Design Archives}}</ref> From 1936 to 1940, he worked on his own as a freelance poster artist. An article on him in the influential journal ''Art and Industry'' in 1937 led to several high-profile commissions for Games, from the [[General Post Office]], [[London Transport (brand)|London Transport]], [[Royal Dutch Shell]] and others.<ref name="Indie"/>
==World War Two== [[File:Join the Ats Art.IWMPST2832.jpg|thumb|''Join the ATS'' (1941) Art.IWMPST2832]] At the start of World War Two, Games was conscripted into the British Army. He served until 1941 when he was approached by the Public Relations Department of the [[War Office]] who were looking for a graphic designer to produce a recruitment poster for the Royal Armoured Corps. From 1942 Games's service as the [[Official War Artist]] for posters resulted in 100 or so posters.<ref name="Pulp">{{cite news|author=Smith, David|date=30 September 2007|title=Poster Churchill pulped on show|work=[[The Observer]]|accessdate=27 August 2013|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2007/sep/30/uk.past}}</ref> Games was allowed a great deal of artistic freedom which enabled him to produce many striking images, often with surrealist elements. Among his first designs was the [[Auxiliary Territorial Service]] recruitment poster that became known as the ''blonde bombshell''. Games had wanted to challenge the rather drab image of the ATS but the authorities feared that the glamorous image he had produced would encourage young women to join the ATS for the "wrong reasons" and the poster was quickly withdrawn.<ref name="RSlocombe"/><ref name="Foss">{{cite book|author=Brain Foss|publisher=Yale University Press|year=2007|title=War paint: Art, War, State and Identity in Britain, 1939-1945 |ISBN=978-0-300-10890-3}}</ref> The design Games replaced it with was criticised by [[Winston Churchill]] as being too "Soviet".
Other notable posters included ''Your Talk May Kill Your Comrades'' (1942) in which a spiral symbolising gossip originates from a soldiers mouth to become a bayonet attacking three of his comrades. Games used the photographic techniques he had learnt from his father in that and other posters such as ''He Talked...They Died'' (1943) part of the ''Careless Talk'' campaign.<ref name="Indie">{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/obituary-abraham-games-1311967.html |title=Obituary:Abraham Games|author=Alan & Isabella Livingston|date=28 August 1996|work=The Independent|accessdate=15 February 2016}}</ref> In addition to his poster work, Games completed a number of commissions for the [[War Artists' Advisory Committee]].<ref name="Foss"/>
Later in the War, Churchill ordered a poster Games had produced to be taken off the wall of the ''Poster Design in Wartime Britain'' exhibition at Harrods in 1943. The [[Army Bureau of Current Affairs]], ABCA, had commissioned Games and [[Frank Newbould]] to produce posters for a series entitled ''Your Britain - Fight for It Now''. While Newbould produced rural images similar to the pre-war travel posters he had created for several railway companies, Games presented a set of three Modernist buildings that had been built to address poverty, disease and deprivation. The poster that annoyed Churchill most featured the [[Berthold Lubetkin]] designed [[Finsbury Health Centre]] superseding a ruined building with a child suffering from rickets. Churchill considered this nothing short of a libel on the conditions in British cities and ordered the poster to be removed.<ref name="RSlocombe"/><ref name="Pulp"/> [[Ernest Bevin]], the war-time [[Secretary of State for Employment|Minister of Labour]], had another poster in the series removed from the ''Poster Design in Wartime Britain'' exhibition organised by the Association of International Artists.<ref name="ODNBag">{{cite book|author= HCG Matthew & Brian Harrison (Editors)|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2004|title=Oxford Dictionary of National Biography Vol 21 (Freudy-Gibberd)|ISBN=0-19-861371-7}}</ref>
==Later career== [[File:Festival of Britain.JPG|thumb|The [[Festival of Britain]] emblem – the [[Festival Star]] – designed by Abram Games, from the cover of the South Bank Exhibition Guide, 1951]] In 1946, Games resumed his freelance practice and worked for clients such Royal Dutch Shell, the ''[[Financial Times]]'', [[Guinness]], [[British Airways]], London Transport and [[El Al]].<ref name=UOBag/> He designed stamps for Britain, Ireland, Israel, Jersey and Portugal.<ref name="Souter, Nick and Tessa 2012 203"/> Also, he designed the logo for the [[JFS (school)|JFS]] school. There were also book jackets for [[Penguin Books]] and logos for the 1951 [[Festival of Britain]] (winning the 1948 competition) and for the 1965 [[Queen's Award to Industry]]. Among his pioneering contributions was, in 1954, the first moving on-screen symbol of BBC Television. He also produced murals. Between 1946 and 1953, Games was a visiting lecturer in graphic design at London's [[Royal College of Art]] and in 1958, was awarded the [[OBE]] for services to graphic design. In 1959, he was appointed a [[Royal Designer for Industry]] (RDI).<ref name="Souter, Nick and Tessa 2012 203"/> He also designed the tile motif of a swan on the [[Victoria line]] platforms at [[Stockwell tube station]] in the late 1960s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://golondon.about.com/od/Victoria-Line-Tile-Motifs/ss/Stockwell.htm|title=Stockwell - Victoria Line Tile Motifs|publisher=Go London|accessdate=27 May 2016}}</ref>
Games had been among the first in Britain to see evidence of the atrocities committed at the [[Bergen-Belsen concentration camp]], when photographs taken there by British troops arrived at the War Office in 1945. The same year he produced a poster, ''Give Clothing for Liberated Jewry'', and would often work to support Jewish and Israeli organisations.<ref name="ODNBag"/> Games, who was Jewish, spent some time in Israel in the 1950s where, among other activities, he designed stamps for the Israeli Post Office, including for the [[Conquest of the Desert (exhibition)|1953 Conquest of the Desert]] exhibition<ref name="stamp">{{cite web|url=http://www.boeliem.com/content/1953/93.html|title=Exhibition 'Conquest Of The Desert'|accessdate=November 22, 2014}}</ref> and taught a course in postage-stamp design. He also designed covers for ''[[The Jewish Chronicle]]'' and prayer book prints for the [[Reform Synagogues of Great Britain]].<ref name="Moore"/> In 1960 Games designed the poster known as ''Freedom from Hunger'' for the [[Food and Agriculture Organization]] of the United Nations.<ref name="Moore">{{cite news |author=Moore, Rowan |url= https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2014/aug/23/abram-games-poster-graphic-design-principles |title=Abram Games, the poster boy with principles |date=23 August 2014|accessdate=24 August 2014|work=[[The Observer]] }}</ref>
Games was also an industrial designer of sorts. Activities in this discipline included the design of the 1947 Cona [[vacuum coffee maker]] (produced from 1949, reworked in 1959 and still in production) and inventions such as a circular vacuum cleaner and an early 1960s portable handheld [[duplicating machine]] by [[Gestetner]], which was not put into production due to the demise of mimeography.
In arriving at a poster design, Games would render up to 30 small preliminary sketches and then combine two or three into the final one. In the developmental process, he would work small because, he asserted, if poster designs "don't work an inch high, they will never work." He would also call on a large number of photographic images as source material. Purportedly, if a client rejected a proposed design (which seldom occurred), Games would resign and suggest that the client commission someone else.
In 2013, the [[National Army Museum]], London, acquired a collection of his posters, each signed by Games and in mint condition.<ref name="NAM">{{cite news|author= Kennedy, Maeve|date=23 August 2013|title=Poster girl of ATS joins National Army Museum|work=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=23 August 2013|url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2013/aug/23/poster-girl-ats-national-army-museum}}</ref> <gallery> File:Jersey deckchair poster.jpg|Poster by Games advertising tourism for the island of [[Jersey]]. File:Fly BEA Jersey tourism advertising poster beach umbrella.jpg|[[British European Airways]] advertising poster by Games. </gallery>

[[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], Canada | type = [[Islamic art|Muslim arts]] and [[Muslim culture|culture]] | director = Henry Kim | curator = | visitors = | map_type = Canada Toronto | map_caption = Location of the museum in Toronto | collection_size = 1,000 | coordinates = {{coord|43.725429|-79.331997|region:CA-ON_type:landmark_scale:2500|display=inline,title}} | publictransit = {{rint|toronto|bus|100}}
{{rint|toronto|subway|5}} ''{{ttcs|Aga Khan}}'' {{small|(opening 2021)}} | website = {{URL|http://www.agakhanmuseum.org/}} }} The '''Aga Khan Museum''' ({{lang-fr|Musée Aga Khan}}) is a museum of [[Islamic art]], [[Iranian art|Iranian (Persian) art]] and [[Muslim culture]] in the [[North York]] district of [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], Canada.{{cite web |title=New Aga Khan Museum To Showcase Cultural Contributions of Muslim Civilisations |url=http://www.artlyst.com/articles/new-aga-khan-museum-to-showcase-cultural-contributions-of-muslim-civilisations |website=Artlyst |accessdate=August 20, 2014}} The museum is an initiative of the [[Aga Khan Trust for Culture]], an agency of the [[Aga Khan Development Network]]. It houses collections of Islamic art and heritage, including artifacts from the private collections of [[Aga Khan IV|His Highness the Aga Khan]], the [[Institute of Ismaili Studies]] in London, and Prince and Princess [[Prince Sadruddin Aga Khan|Sadruddin Aga Khan]], which showcase the artistic, intellectual and scientific contributions of Muslim civilizations. ==History== [[File:Toronto, Canada (20311020513).jpg|thumb|left|The building of the museum was designed by [[Fumihiko Maki]].]] In 1996, the Aga Khan bought the property 77 Wynford Drive from Shell Corporation. In 2002, he bought the adjacent property, which was formerly the [[Bata Shoes Head Office]]. On October 8, 2002, the Aga Khan Development Network (AKDN) announced the establishment of the Aga Khan Museum, [[Ismaili Centre, Toronto|Ismaili Centre]] and Park on the site.{{cite press release|url=http://www.akdn.org/press_release/551/Aga-Khan-to-Establish-Major-Academic-and-Cultural-Center-and-Museum-in-Canada |title=Aga Khan to Establish Major Academic and Cultural Center and Museum in Canada |publisher=[[Aga Khan Development Network]] |date=October 8, 2002 |accessdate=April 28, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081207033210/http://www.akdn.org/press_release/551/Aga-Khan-to-Establish-Major-Academic-and-Cultural-Center-and-Museum-in-Canada |archivedate=December 7, 2008 }} Although heritage groups wanted it preserved, the modernist Bata Shoes building was demolished in 2007 to make way for the project. The foundation-laying ceremony for the project was performed by [[Prime Minister of Canada|Canadian Prime Minister]] [[Stephen Harper]] and the Aga Khan on May 28, 2010.{{Cite web| url=http://www.theismaili.org/cms/1012/Mawlana-Hazar-Imam-in-Toronto-for-Foundation-Ceremony | title=Mawlana Hazar Imam is awarded Honorary Canadian Citizenship as he is joined by Prime Minister for Foundation Ceremony in Toronto | date=May 28, 2010 |publisher=TheIsmaili.org |accessdate=May 30, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100601082541/http://www.theismaili.org/cms/1012/Mawlana-Hazar-Imam-in-Toronto-for-Foundation-Ceremony| archivedate= June 1, 2010 | deadurl= no}} The museum was designed by [[Pritzker Prize]] winner [[Fumihiko Maki]]. The 10,000 square-metre structure is set within formal gardens and surrounded by a large park ([[Aga Khan Park]]) designed by landscape architect [[Vladimir Djurovic]].{{Cite book| title = Spirit & Life: Masterpieces of Islamic Art from the Aga Khan Museum Collection | publisher = The Aga Khan Trust for Culture | year = 2007 | location = Switzerland | isbn = 978-2-940212-02-6}} The extensive site is shared with a new Ismaili Centre designed by the [[India]]n architect [[Charles Correa]].{{Cite news|url=http://archrecord.construction.com/news/daily/archives/081006AghaKhan.asp |title=Correa, Maki Tapped to Design Aga Khan Center |date=October 6, 2008 |publisher=Architectural Record, The McGraw-Hill Companies |accessdate=October 9, 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081007213131/http://archrecord.construction.com/news/daily/archives/081006AghaKhan.asp| archivedate= October 7, 2008 | deadurl= no}} Maki, Djurovic and Correa worked in collaboration with the Toronto-based architectural firm Moriyama and Teshima, who worked as the architect of record on the project.Rochon, Lisa. "Maki's Aga Khan Museum Makes its Debut". Architectural Record. October 2014, pp. 25-26. The museum opened on September 18, 2014.Rochon, Lisa: [http://archrecord.construction.com/news/2014/09/140919-Makis-Aga-Khan-Museum-Makes-Its-Debut.asp "Maki's Aga Khan Museum Makes Its Debut"], in ''The Architectural Record'', September 19, 2014 ==Collection== [[File:Interior view - Aga Khan Museum - Toronto, Canada - DSC06599.jpg|thumb|Works from the museum's collection are displayed in exhibits throughout the museum.]] The museum is dedicated to the acquisition, preservation, display and interpretation of artefacts relating to the intellectual, cultural, artistic and religious traditions of [[Muslim]] communities, past and present. Artefacts include [[Ceramic art|ceramics]], [[metalwork]], and paintings covering all periods of [[Islamic history]]. [[Manuscripts]] in the collection include the earliest known copy of [[Avicenna]]'s [[The Canon of Medicine|Qanun fi'l-Tibb]] ("The Canon of Medicine") dated 1052. A music programme is planned, which will work to expand knowledge of the traditional music of [[Asia]] and the [[Islamic world]], as well as their contemporary expression. The museum will become a repository of historical materials related to the [[Ismaili]] community and house research programmes related to each one of the aspects of its institutional mission. It will also provide a space for permanent exchanges between the Islamic and the [[Western world]]s on educational, cultural and socio-economic issues. The collection, which comprises some 1,000 objects,{{Cite web|url=http://www.theismaili.org/cms/999/Aga-Khan-Museum-Collection-reflects-pluralism-of-the-Muslim-world-and-shared-human-heritage |title=Aga Khan Museum Collection reflects pluralism of the Muslim world and shared human heritage |author=Mehnaz Thawer |date=May 20, 2010 |publisher=TheIsmaili.org |accessdate=May 24, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100524024154/http://www.theismaili.org/cms/999/Aga-Khan-Museum-Collection-reflects-pluralism-of-the-Muslim-world-and-shared-human-heritage| archivedate= May 24, 2010 | deadurl= no}} includes several superb examples of [[Qur'an]] manuscripts that demonstrate the variety of script, media and decorative styles that evolved in the Muslim world. Among them, an eighth century [[North Africa]]n folio demonstrates the earliest style of [[Kufic script]] written on [[parchment]]. A page from the well known ''[[Blue Qur'an]]'' provides an example of gold kufic script on indigo-dyed parchment. The Blue Qur'an is considered one of the most extraordinary Qur'an manuscripts ever created; its origins are 9th-tenth century North African, and it was likely created for the [[Fatimid]] caliphs ruling from [[Qayrawan]]. ==European tour== While a permanent home was being built for the collection, selected items went on tour in Europe. December 2, 2007 }} The exhibit conveys both ''[[Dīn]]'' and ''[[Dunya]]'', which can be translated as 'Spirit & Life' — the religious and secular aspects of life which are inextricably linked in Muslim cultures. The first exhibitions were organized in two parts: ''The Word of God'' consisting of sacred texts and related objects and ''The Power of the Sovereign'' reflecting Muslim courts and their figures. More recent exhibitions have been organized as ''The Word of God'' and ''The Route of the Travellers'' showing the geographic breadth of the Islamic world. ==In popular culture== *The museum appeared in the ''[[Star Trek: Discovery]]'' episode "[[Lethe (Star Trek: Discovery)|Lethe]]", where it was used as a filming location for scenes on the planet [[Vulcan (Star Trek)|Vulcan]]. *The scientific revision.text:
The '''debate between Bill Nye and Ken Ham''' on the question "Is Creation A Viable Model of Origins?" was held February 4, 2014, at the [[Creation Museum]] in [[Petersburg, Boone County, Kentucky|Petersburg, Kentucky]].
[[Ken Ham|Ham]], founder and chief executive officer of the [[Young Earth creationism|Young Earth creationist]] (YEC) ministry [[Answers in Genesis]] (AiG), challenged [[Bill Nye|Nye]], a science educator best known for hosting the 1990s television series ''[[Bill Nye the Science Guy]]'', to the debate after taking exception to a [[YouTube]] video featuring Nye lamenting the refusal of a large segment of the U.S. population to accept [[evolution]]. Tickets to the event sold out within minutes, and according to a Christian public relations firm an estimated 3 million people viewed the event live via [[Streaming media|video streams]] on the Internet. During the debate, Ham advocated the legitimacy of a YEC model of the universe's origins, while Nye cited observations from a variety of scientific fields to defend the [[scientific consensus]] that the Earth is [[Age of the Earth|approximately 4.5 billion years old]].
Many scientists were critical of Nye for accepting Ham's invitation, claiming his participation in the debate gave Ham's views undeserved legitimacy, but two [[humanism|humanist]] groups – the [[American Humanist Association]] and the [[Center for Inquiry]] – praised Nye's decision. Scientists, both Christian and non-Christian, generally agreed that Nye won the debate, at least in terms of the science presented, although they debated how convincing the victory was.<ref name=Biologos>{{cite web|url=http://biologos.org/blog/ham-on-nye-our-take|title=Ham on Nye: Our Take|date=February 5, 2014|publisher=[[Biologos Foundation|The Biologos Foundation]]|accessdate=May 3, 2014|quote=Emily Ruppel, Deborah Haarsma, Jim Stump, John Walton, Dennis Venema, and Ted Davis.}}</ref> Ham later announced that the publicity generated by the debate had spurred fundraising for AiG's planned [[Ark Encounter]] theme park, allowing the ministry to begin construction. Both Ham and Nye have since released books on the debate.<ref name="NYT-20141103-JD">{{cite news |last=Deiviscio |first=Jeffrey |title=A Fight for the Young Creationist Mind - In 'Undeniable,' Bill Nye Speaks Evolution Directly to Creationists |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/11/04/science/in-undeniable-bill-nye-speaks-evolution-directly-to-creationists.html |date=November 3, 2014 |work=[[New York Times]] |accessdate=November 4, 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://answersingenesis.org/store/product/inside-nye-ham-debate/|title=Inside the Nye Ham Debate|website=Answers in Genesis|language=en-US|access-date=2018-02-10}}</ref>
==Background== [[File:Bill Nye speaking at Jesse Hall.jpg|thumb|Bill Nye]] On August 23, 2012, the [[Internet forum]] [[Big Think]] posted a video entitled "Creationism is Not Appropriate for Children" on [[YouTube]].<ref name=nyeyoutube>{{cite AV media |people=[[Bill Nye|Nye, Bill]] |year=2012 |title=Creationism is Not Appropriate for Children |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gHbYJfwFgOU |accessdate=February 11, 2014 |publisher=[[Big Think]]}}</ref> The video featured [[Bill Nye]], best known for hosting the children's educational television program ''[[Bill Nye the Science Guy]]'' during the 1990s, lamenting that a significant portion of the U.S. population does not believe in [[evolution]], asserting that this disbelief has a detrimental impact on science education in the U.S., and encouraging parents who have doubts about evolution not to teach them to their children "because we need them."<ref name=lovan2012>{{cite news |last=Lovan |first=Dylan |title=Bill Nye warns: Creation views threaten US science |agency=AP Online |date=September 24, 2012 |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1A1-07009c71ef51419a98865a691635f294.html}}</ref> In a follow-up interview with the [[Associated Press]], Nye said, "If we raise a generation of students who don't believe in the process of science, who think everything that we've come to know about nature and the universe can be dismissed by a few sentences translated into English from some ancient text, you're not going to continue to innovate."<ref name=lovan2012 /> By September 2012, the Associated Press reported that Nye's video had been viewed 4.6 million times and garnered 186,000 comments.<ref name=lovan2012 />
[[File:Ken Ham.jpg|thumb|upright|Ken Ham]] Days after the Nye video was posted, the YEC ministry [[Answers in Genesis]] (AiG) posted a video response featuring AiG scientists [[David Menton]] and [[Georgia Purdom]].<ref name=hamresponse>{{cite web |last=Ham |first=Ken |authorlink=Ken Ham |title=Time is Nye for a Rebuttal |work=Answers with Ken Ham |publisher=Answers in Genesis |date=August 29, 2012 |url=http://blogs.answersingenesis.org/blogs/ken-ham/2012/08/29/time-is-nye-for-a-rebuttal/ |accessdate=February 11, 2014}}</ref> AiG founder and executive director [[Ken Ham]] also objected to the claims in Nye's video in a post on his blog, ''Answers with Ken Ham''.<ref name=hamresponse /> Soon after, Ham began trying to convince Nye to visit AiG's [[Creation Museum]] in [[Petersburg, Boone County, Kentucky|Petersburg, Kentucky]], which presents a YEC viewpoint that the Earth was created by the God of the Bible approximately 6,000 years ago and dinosaurs and humans once co-existed, based on a literal reading of the book of [[Book of Genesis|Genesis]], in contrast to the [[scientific consensus]] that the Earth is [[Age of the Earth|approximately 4.5 billion years old]] and the existence of dinosaurs and humans is separated by about 60 million years.<ref name=debateset>{{cite news |last=Lovan |first=Dylan |title=Bill Nye to visit Creation Museum for debate |agency=AP Online |date=January 2, 2014 |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1A1-55831a179e1849e6a16b5ebdf53d4afd.html}}</ref> On January 2, 2014, Ham announced on his [[Facebook]] page that Nye had accepted his invitation to a debate at the museum.<ref name=debateset /> AiG agreed to pay Nye's travel expenses, and the date – February 4, 2014 – was close to one of Nye's previously-scheduled speaking engagements at Kentucky's [[Murray State University]].<ref name=debateset /><ref name= nyetodebate>{{cite news |last=Poulisse |first=Adam |title=Bill Nye to Debate Evolution with Creationist in Kentucky |newspaper=[[Pasadena Star-News]] |date=January 3, 2014 |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-35539086.html}}</ref> In an AiG press release, Ham commented that "having the opportunity to hold a cordial but spirited debate with such a well-known personality who is admired by so many young people will help bring the creation-evolution issue to the attention of many more people, including youngsters."<ref name=debateset /> Of Ham and AiG, Nye said, "This guy and his beliefs are in their midst, and we can't have this way of thinking for our science students, to have people like this organization try to insinuate themselves in our schools is not appropriate and a formula for a darker future."<ref name=nyetodebate /> Nye told the Associated Press that he didn't mind holding the debate at the Creation Museum: "It either makes me anxious, or it's an opportunity to influence that many more people and, frankly, have that much more fun."<ref name=nyetodebate />
Many in the scientific community were critical of Nye's decision to participate in the event, claiming it lent undue credibility to the [[creationist]] worldview.<ref name=csm>{{cite news |last=Chowdhury |first=Sudeshna |title=Bill Nye vs. Ken Ham: Should Scientists Bother Debating Creationists? |magazine=[[Christian Science Monitor]] |date=February 3, 2014 |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-357509370.html}}</ref> [[Biologos Foundation|The Biologos Foundation]], an organization promoting the compatibility of [[Relationship between religion and science|science and religion]], released a statement advocating [[evolutionary creation]], maintaining the position "that you don't have to choose. You don't have to give up Christian faith in order to accept the best, most compelling science. We expect that we'll agree with most of what Bill Nye will say about the science of evolution. Fossils, genetics, and other disciplines give compelling evidence that all life on earth is related and developed over a very long time through natural processes. But we're also brothers and sisters in Christ with Ken Ham. We believe that Jesus is the Son of God, that he died for our sins and rose from the dead, and that the Bible is the authoritative word of God."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://biologos.org/blog/ken-ham-vs-bill-nye|title=Ken Ham vs. Bill Nye|last=Haarsma|first=Deborah|date=January 15, 2014|publisher=[[The BioLogos Foundation]]|accessdate=May 3, 2014}}</ref> Others expressed concern that Nye's relative lack of familiarity with evolution – his formal training is in [[mechanical engineering]] – and inexperience in debates might lead some to conclude that Ham won the debate.<ref name=csm /> "I am by no means an expert on most of this," Nye later admitted, but added, "In this situation, our skeptical arguments are not the stuff of Ph.Ds. It's elementary science and common sense."<ref name=underestimate>{{cite news |last=Lovan |first=Dylan T. |title=Bill Nye says he underestimated debate's impact |agency=AP Online |date=April 16, 2014 |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1A1-6423e6ff064f4ca38c7ef4b56fa04bea.html}}</ref> In preparation for the event, Nye had lunch with scientists who specialize in evolutionary theory and traveled to [[Oakland, California]], to meet with the staff of [[National Center for Science Education]] (NCSE), an advocacy group for teaching evolution.<ref name=underestimate /> In an op-ed for [[CNN]], Nye answered critics, saying, "In short, I decided to participate in the debate because I felt it would draw attention to the importance of science education here in the United States."<ref name=nyewhy>{{cite web |last=Nye |first=Bill |authorlink=Bill Nye |title=Why I'm debating creationist Ken Ham |publisher=[[CNN]] |date=February 4, 2014 |url=http://religion.blogs.cnn.com/2014/02/04/why-im-debating-creationist-ken-ham/ |accessdate=February 12, 2014}}</ref> He later conceded that he had underestimated the debate's impact, saying he expected it to draw attention comparable to his scholarly presentations at college campuses.<ref name=underestimate />
Leaders of two [[humanism|humanist]] groups – the [[American Humanist Association]] (AHA) and the [[Center for Inquiry]] – praised Nye's decision to participate in the debate.<ref name=wapo>{{cite news |last=Winston |first=Kimberly |title=Ham-on-Nye debate pits atheists, creationists |newspaper=[[Washington Post]] |date=January 30, 2014 |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/religion/ham-on-nye-debate-pits-atheists-creationists/2014/01/30/140d58ee-89ec-11e3-a760-a86415d0944d_story.html |accessdate=February 12, 2014}}</ref> AHA director of development and communications Maggie Ardiente told the ''[[Washington Post]]'', "I am looking at statistics and they tell me people like Ken Ham and other creationists are being very effective and that is a serious problem. We can't just ignore that. We have to challenge people like Ken Ham so I support the debate 100 percent."<ref name=wapo /> [[Debbie Goddard]], the Center for Inquiry's director of outreach, concurred: "If we don't let [creationists'] ideas see the light of day we can't develop the tools to address them. And we don't just need the tools of facts and evidence, but also of understanding their views and compassion for them if we want to be effective at changing their minds."<ref name=wapo />
==Attendance and viewership== [[File:Creation Museum Legacy Hall.jpg|thumb|Legacy Hall, the site of the debate]] Tickets to the debate, entitled "Is Creation A Viable Model of Origins?" and held in the Creation Museum's 900-seat Legacy Hall, went on sale for $25 each on January 6 and sold out within minutes.<ref name=sellout>{{cite news |title=Bill Nye Debate Tickets Already Sold Out |newspaper=The Gazette |date=January 6, 2014 |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-35546566.html}}</ref> Creation Museum officials reported that tickets were sold to residents of 29 different states.<ref name=lovandebate>{{cite news |last=Lovan |first=Dylan |title=Bill Nye defends evolution in Kentucky debate |agency=AP Online |date=February 4, 2014 |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1A1-02955366f8954fa09df33c0d19f5ab9a.html}}</ref> Ham told ''[[The Daily Beast]]'' that "the ticket sales won't come to half the cost of the debate."<ref name=dailybeast>{{cite web |last=Schulson |first=Michael |title=The Bill Nye-Ken Ham Debate Was a Nightmare for Science |publisher=[[The Daily Beast]] |date=February 5, 2014 |url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2014/02/05/the-bill-nye-ken-ham-debate-was-a-nightmare-for-science.html |accessdate=February 5, 2014}}</ref>
Over 70 media credentials were distributed for the event.<ref name=media>{{cite news |last=Zaimov |first=Stoyan |title=Bill Nye, Ken Ham Creationism Debate Preview: Mass Media Coverage Surrounding Event |magazine=[[Christian Post]] |date=February 4, 2014 |url=http://global.christianpost.com/news/bill-nye-ken-ham-creationism-debate-preview-mass-media-coverage-surrounding-event-113968/ |accessdate=February 12, 2014}}</ref> The debate was [[Streaming media|streamed]] live over the Internet at debatelive.org and [[Google Hangouts|Google+ Hangouts On Air]].<ref name=livestream>{{cite news |title=University of Cincinnati Geology Club to Broadcast Bill Nye, Ken Ham Debate on Creation |agency=U.S. Federal News Service |date=January 31, 2014 |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P3-3199913191.html}}</ref> Approximately 750,000 computers logged into the live stream.<ref name=zaimov>{{cite news |last=Zaimov |first=Stoyan |title=Bill Nye, Ken Ham Discuss Humans and Dinosaurs With Piers Morgan; Reactions to Creationist Debate |magazine=[[Christian Post]] |date=February 5, 2014 |url=http://global.christianpost.com/news/bill-nye-ken-ham-discuss-humans-and-dinosaurs-with-piers-morgan-reactions-to-creationist-debate-114043/ |accessdate=February 12, 2014}}</ref> The event was widely discussed on Facebook and [[Twitter]], with commenters frequently employing the [[hashtag]] #HamonNye.<ref name=underestimate /> Approximately 10,000 groups from churches, schools, and colleges informed AiG of their intent to host viewing groups.<ref name=media /> Christian public relations firm A. Larry Ross Communications estimated that almost 3 million people viewed the event live over the Internet.<ref name=zaimov /><ref>{{cite news|last=Saroyan|first=Strawberry|title=Christianity, the Brand|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/04/16/magazine/16christian.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0|accessdate=4 May 2014|newspaper=The New York Times|date=April 16, 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Sweet Spot|url=http://alarryross.com/sweet-spot/|publisher=A Larry Ross|accessdate=4 May 2014}}</ref> Immediately after the debate, video footage was made available via YouTube.<ref name=livestream /> [[C-SPAN]] aired the debate on February 19, 2014.<ref name=media />
==Debate== [[Tom Foreman]], a [[broadcast journalist]] from CNN, was chosen to moderate the debate.<ref name=redlands>{{cite news |last=Poulisse |first=Adam |title=Evolution vs. Creation: Bill Nye, Ken Ham Debate the Origins of Life |newspaper=[[Redlands Daily Facts]] |date=February 5, 2014 |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-35661051.html}}</ref> Each man was allowed a five-minute opening statement, followed by a thirty-minute presentation of the evidence for his side; each man was then given five minutes to rebut the other's arguments, and then the floor was opened for questions that the audience had previously submitted on cards.<ref name=redlands /><ref name=format>{{cite news |title=Red House Church to Host Creationism Debate |newspaper=[[The Charleston Gazette]] |date=January 29, 2014 |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-35633054.html}}</ref> Ham won the [[coin toss]] to determine which man delivered his opening statement first.<ref name=redlands />
The debate lasted two and a half hours.<ref name=lovandebate /> During his opening statement, Ham declared, "I believe science has been hijacked by secularists."<ref name=redlands /> He followed up by pointing to several examples of scientists who profess a belief in YEC, most notably [[Raymond Vahan Damadian]], a pioneer in the field of [[magnetic resonance imaging]].<ref name=whowon>{{cite news |last=Chowdhury |first=Sudeshna |title=Bill Nye versus Ken Ham: Who Won? |magazine=Christian Science Monitor |date=February 5, 2014 |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-357806905.html}}</ref>
Ham also drew a distinction between "historical science" and "observational science", a distinction the ''[[Christian Science Monitor]]'' notes is unique to creation scientists.<ref name=whowon /> "We observe things in the present, and we're assuming that has always happened in the past," said Ham, adding, "You've got a problem, because you weren't there."<ref name=5arguments>{{cite news |last=O'Neil |first=Tyler |title=Science vs. Bible? 5 Arguments for and Against Creationism From the Ken Ham, Bill Nye Debate |magazine=[[Christian Post]] |date=February 5, 2014 |url=http://global.christianpost.com/news/science-vs-bible-the-5-best-arguments-for-and-against-creationism-from-the-ken-ham-bill-nye-debate-114005/pageall.html |accessdate=February 12, 2014}}</ref> During his rebuttal, Nye asked, "Why should we accept your word for it that natural law changed 3,000 years ago and we have no record of it?"<ref name=5arguments />
Nye cited [[radiometric dating]], [[ice core]] data, and the light from distant stars to argue that the Earth must be much older than young Earth creationists like Ham theorize.<ref name=whowon /> Ham argued that these various dating methods are untrustworthy because they often give varying ages for the same artifacts.<ref name=5arguments />
The [[Genesis flood narrative]], which Nye repeatedly referred to as "Ken Ham's great flood", was a major topic of discussion, with Nye arguing that a boat constructed according to the parameters given for [[Noah's Ark]] in the [[Book of Genesis]] would not float.<ref name=redlands /><ref name=whowon /> Nye also calculated that, if there were 7,000 "kinds" of animals on the Ark, on average, 11 new species would have had to come into existence every day for the Earth to contain all presently known species.<ref name=5arguments />
Towards the end of the debate, Ham admitted that nothing would change his mind concerning his views on [[creationism]], whereas Nye acknowledged that, if enough convincing evidence were presented to him, he would change his mind immediately.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Arel|first1=Dan|title=Did Bill Nye Hurt Science|url=http://new.www.huffingtonpost.com/dan-arel/did-bill-nye-hurt-science_b_4733386.html|website=www.huffingtonpost|publisher=HuffingtonPost.Inc|accessdate=13 February 2017}}</ref>
==Reaction== No score was kept to declare a winner in the debate.<ref name=underestimate /> Prior to the event, Ham commented, "I don't see it as a debate to win or lose. I don't believe people should go away saying 'Bill Nye won' or 'Ken Ham won.' I want to passionately deal with what I believe, and I want Bill Nye to passionately speak on what he believes."<ref name=redlands /> In a letter published in ''[[Skeptical Inquirer]]'' after the debate, Nye wrote that by "a strong majority of accounts, I bested him."<ref name=underestimate />
[[File:Jerry Coyne, American professor of biology at the University of Chicago.jpg|thumb|upright|Biologist Jerry Coyne wrote that Nye won the debate.]] Scientists typically stated that Nye won the debate.<ref name=whowon /> [[University of Chicago]] biologist [[Jerry Coyne]] contested Ham's distinction between historical science and observational science: "Science based on historical reconstruction, when done properly, is just as valid as science based on direct, real-time observation."<ref name=whowon /> While Coyne felt the debate may have given undeserved credibility to the creationist viewpoint, he concluded that, "The debate was Ham's to win and he lost. And the debate was Nye's to lose and he won."<ref name=whowon /> Science blogger [[Greg Laden]], who had earlier expressed concerns about Nye's lack of evolutionary expertise, believed Nye's victory was as lop-sided as the [[Seattle Seahawks]]' victory over the [[Denver Broncos]] in the recently played [[Super Bowl XLVIII]].<ref name=whowon /> He noted that Nye charmed the "evangelical audience" with his style, while the NCSE noted that Ham – "no mean orator", according to the NCSE – "sometimes rambled far afield, and [his presentation] often raced by so quickly that it was hard even to know what he was saying".<ref name=whowon /> ''[[Daily Beast]]'' writer Michael Schulson, however, used the same Seahawks-Broncos analogy to declare Ham the resounding victor. Although Schulson agreed with Nye's underlying scientific message, and allowed that Nye "had his moments," he wrote that "it was easy to pick out the smarter man on the stage. Oddly, it was the same man who was arguing that the earth is 6,000 years old." He believed that Ham's simpler presentation made him sound like "a reasonable human being", while Nye lost his audience by "sounding like a clueless geek, even if his points were scientifically valid".<ref name=dailybeast />
Evangelical blogger Ezra Byer credited Ham with raising awareness of the Christian message, but felt he failed to provide compelling factual evidence for his beliefs.<ref name=whowon /> As partial explanation, Byer noted, "As I watched Mr. Ham's mannerisms, you could sense a tremendous Spirit about him. He was gracious and the power of God showed through his life. There were multiple times I believed he could have hammered Nye on some of his inconsistencies but in my opinion chose not to."<ref name=whowon />
[[Biologos Foundation|The Biologos Foundation]] stated "that one of the lasting effects of this debate will be to further alienate Christianity from science in the public consciousness."<ref name=Biologos/> The [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] said that the debate "drew world attention, once again, on the United States as the home of whacky Christianity."<ref name="ABC">{{cite news |url= http://www.abc.net.au/religion/articles/2014/03/20/3968199.htm |title= Too Much Faith in Schools: The Rise of Christian Schooling in Australia |department= Opinion: ABC Religion & Ethics |first= Marion |last= Maddox |date=March 2014 |work=[[ABC Online|ABC Online (Australian Broadcasting Network)]] |accessdate= 15 April 2014}}</ref>
[[Michael Behe]], a biologist at [[Lehigh University]] and an advocate of [[intelligent design]], felt that by "talking on about the age of the Earth [rather] than on the elegance and complexities of life", both Ham and Nye lost the debate.<ref name=whowon /> [[Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of America#The Episcopacy|Metropolitan Nicholas]] of the Greek Orthodox Church, who was trained as a scientist before taking [[holy orders]], also criticized both Nye's and Ham's approach to the debate, saying that "Research that is done to challenge God, has the disease of prejudice. Research is done to discover scientific truth. What problem is there with someone wanting to broaden the horizons of their thoughts and knowledge? God is approached better this way. God is not an ideology that we should by all means defend, but we believe in Him because He is Truth. In this sense, even scientific truth reveals Him. If He is still questioned, it is time to find out about Him. A believer who fears scientific research, fears the truth. Perhaps he is a believer who does not believe."<ref name="Nicholas">{{cite web|url=http://www.theamericanconservative.com/dreher/ken-ham-bill-nye-meet-biologos-metropolitan-nicholas/|title=Ken Ham & Bill Nye, Meet Met. Nicholas & BioLogos}}</ref>
On February 27, 2014, Ham announced that the publicity the debate generated for AiG had spurred fundraising for its stalled [[Ark Encounter]] project, allowing the first phase of construction – a {{convert|510|ft|m|adj=on}} reconstruction of Noah's Ark estimated to cost $73 million – to begin.<ref name=arkpark>{{cite news |title=Noah's Ark Project Spurred by Evolution Debate |newspaper=The Gazette |date=February 27, 2014 |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-35743340.html}}</ref> Following the announcement, Nye told the Associated Press he hopes the project "goes out of business", adding "If [Ham] builds that ark, it's my strong opinion, it's bad for the commonwealth of Kentucky and bad for scientists based in Kentucky and bad for the U.S. And I'm not joking, bad for the world."<ref name=arkpark />

Carolyn Murphy biography, pictures, measurements, photo gallery |publisher=videofashion |date= |accessdate=2010-12-26}} is an [[United States|American]] [[model (person)|model]] and [[actress]].{{cite web|url=http://www.designerzcentral.com/fashion-models/25-carolyn-murphy/ |title="DC" All on Designerz Central |publisher=designerzcentral.com |date= |accessdate=2009-05-05}} ==Biography== In 1998, Murphy was named VH1/''Vogue''{{'}}s Model of the Year. She played Dubbie in [[Barry Levinson]]'s film ''[[Liberty Heights]]''.{{cite web|last=Rainer |first=Peter |url=http://nymag.com/nymetro/movies/reviews/1572/ |title="Liberty Heights,""Sleepy Hollow," and "The World Is Not Enough" |publisher=Nymag.com |date=1998-11-29 |accessdate=2010-12-26}} She was one of the "Modern Muses" on the November 1999 millennium cover of American ''[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]''{{cite web|url=http://www.sassybella.com/2007/04/vogues-worlds-next-top-models-cover/|title=Vogue’s ‘World’s Next Top Models’ cover|last=Lee|first=Helen|date=April 11, 2007|publisher=SassyBella.com|accessdate=April 18, 2011}} and was chosen to represent [[Calvin Klein]]'s perfume, ''Contradiction''.{{cite web|url=http://www.askmen.com/celebs/women/models_100/118_carolyn_murphy.html#famous |title=Carolyn Murphy Pictures, Photo Galleries, Bio & Rating |publisher=AskMen |date=1975-08-11 |accessdate=2010-12-26}} In 1998, during a photo shoot for ''[[Elle (magazine)|Elle]]'', the photographer noticed her resemblance to the actress [[Gene Tierney]] and dubbed her "The blonde Gene Tierney".''Elle'', September issue 1998. Murphy has shot campaigns for [[Missoni]], [[Versace]] and [[Tiffany & Co.]]{{cite web|url=http://www.fashionmodeldirectory.com/models/carolyn_murphy/photos/ads.htm |title=FMD — ads Photos of carolyn murphy |publisher=Fashionmodeldirectory.com |date= |accessdate=2010-12-26}} In 2005 she was featured on the cover of the [[Sports Illustrated Swimsuit Issue|''Sports Illustrated'' Swimsuit Issue]].{{cite web|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/swimsuit/collection/issues/2005/ |title=SI.com — Swimsuit Collection - 2005 Issue |publisher=Sportsillustrated.cnn.com |date= |accessdate=2010-12-26}} In July 2012, Murphy was hired to replace [[Angela Lindvall]] as host of ''[[Project Runway: All Stars]]'' on Lifetime, after [[Rosie Huntington-Whiteley]] dropped out for a film project.{{cite web|title=Model drives ’em ‘Mad’|url=http://www.nypost.com/p/pagesix/model_drives_em_mad_X2wcgZ0uBLSedxG7GkYRdN|work=New York Post|accessdate=September 27, 2012|date=July 8, 2012}} In 2012, Murphy was ninth on the ''[[Forbes]]'' top-earning models list, estimated to have earned $3.5 million in one year.{{cite web |first= Brian |last=Solomon |title=The World's Highest Paid Models: Carolyn Murphy |url=https://www.forbes.com/pictures/eimh45elij/no-9-carolyn-murphy/|work=Forbes.com |publisher=Forbes.com LLC |date=June 14, 2012 |accessdate=2012-06-20}} As of 2015, Murphy and boyfriend Lincoln Pilcher practice [[Transcendental Meditation technique|Transcendental Meditation]].{{cite web|last1=Whitney|first1=Christine|title=Fabulous at every age: Carolyn Murphy|website=Harpers Bazaar|accessdate=March 13, 2015|date=March 12, 2015|quote=Her regimen is extensive: alkaline water; eight to 10 hours of sleep; biodynamic vegetables; frequent sauna sessions; Estée Lauder Youth-Dew; power crystals; and Transcendental Meditation (boyfriend Lincoln Pilcher's childhood friend taught the couple the technique).}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{SI Swimsuit Cover Models}} {{2000–2009 Sports Illustrated Swimsuit}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Murphy, Carolyn}} [[Category:1974 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Female models from Florida]] [[Category:Choctawhatchee High School alumni]] [[Category:IMG Models models]] [[Category:Participants in American reality television series]] [[Category:People from Panama City, Florida]] [[Category:Transcendental Meditation practitioners]]

Rabbi Yitzchak Shaul (Shuki) Kanievsky{{cite book|last1=Weinberger|first1=Naftali|last2=Weinberger|first2=Naomi|last3=Indig|first3=Nina|editor1-first=Nosson|editor1-last=Scherman|editor1-link=Nosson Scherman|editor2-first=Meir|editor2-last=Zlotowitz|editor2-link=Meir Zlotowitz|title=Rebbetzin Kanievsky: A Legendary Mother to All|edition=2nd|url=http://www.artscroll.com/Products/RKANH.html|accessdate=July 22, 2013|year=2012|publisher=[[Mesorah Publications]]|isbn=9781422612064}}{{rp|24}} | occupation = | profession = | alma_mater = | semicha = | signature = }} '''Shmaryahu Yosef Chaim Kanievsky''' (b. 1928) is an [[Israel]]i [[rabbi]] and ''[[posek]]'' living in [[Bnei Brak]], [[Israel]].{{cite web|url=https://www.nerechad.org/about-rabbi-chaim |title=About Rabbi Chaim |publisher=Nerechad.org |date= |accessdate=2017-02-13}} Kanievsky is considered a leading authorityhttp://acheinu.co.il/?CategoryID=487&ArticleID=6061 in [[Haredi Judaism|Haredi Jewish]] society.http://artscroll.com/Books/9781422618684.html http://blog.aishhaolam.com/2016/11/recommendations-by-the-gadol-hador-rav-chaim-kanievsky-to-merit-children/ == Biography == [[File:Rebchaim.JPG|thumb|A visitor seeking the rabbi's advice]] Kanievsky was born January 8, 1928, in [[Pinsk]], [[Second Polish Republic]], to Rabbi [[Yaakov Yisrael Kanievsky]] (also known as the Steipler Gaon) and Rebbitzen Miriam Karelitz, sister of Rabbi [[Avrohom Yeshaya Karelitz|Avraham Yeshayahu Karelitz]] (also known as the Chazon Ish). He married [[Batsheva Kanievsky|Batsheva Elyashiv]], daughter of Rabbi [[Yosef Sholom Eliashiv]] (grandson of Rav [[Shlomo Elyashiv]], also known as the Leshem) and granddaughter of Rav [[Aryeh Levin]] (known as the "[[Tzadik|Tzaddik]] of [[Jerusalem]]"). During the 1948 [[Israeli War of Independence]], Rav Kanievsky, then a student at the Lomza Yeshiva, was conscripted for temporary army service in the general mobilization. He was assigned to stand guard on a large hill near [[Jaffa]].{{rp|376}} Rabbi Kanievsky's wife died in 2011. He lives in Bnei Brak, and receives thousands of visitors every year from Jews seeking religious advice.{{cite web|url=https://www.rabbimeirbaalhaneis.com/Rabbi%20Chaim%20Kanievsky.asp |title=Biography of Rabbi Chaim Kanievsky (born 1928) and his relationship to the Rabbi Meir Baal Haneis charity in Israel |publisher=Rabbimeirbaalhaneis.com |date= |accessdate=2017-02-13}} Kanievsky is the official rabbi and spiritual guide for the non-profit organization Belev Echad, which was founded in Israel on 2011 and is dedicated to assist sick and disabled children and adults.{{cite web |url=https://www.virtualjudaica.com/Listing/Details/505256/Letter-by-8-important-rabbis-Bnei-Brak-2011 |title=Letter by R. Hayyim Kanievsky}} It has been recognised by the haredi community since the passing of Rav Steinman in December 2017, that Rav Chaim Kanievsky and Rav Gershon Edelstein are the leaders of the haredi community.[1]{{Cite web|url=https://www.vosizneias.com/286933/2017/12/13/jerusalem-analysis-after-rav-shteinman-passing-who-will-lead-the-haredim/|title=Jerusalem - Analysis: After Rav Shteinman Passing Who Will Lead The Haredim|website=www.vosizneias.com|access-date=2018-01-13}} Since his arrival to Israel as a young boy, Rabbi Kanievsky has never left the Holy Land to visit other countries. == Statements and rulings == In 2012, Rav Kanievsky ruled that it is forbidden to possess or use a smartphone without individual permission from a halakhic authority, and that owners are not allowed to sell their phones, but should instead burn them.{{cite web|last=Ari |first=Judah |url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/burn-your-iphones-leading-rabbi-rules/ |title=Burn your iPhones, top rabbi orders |publisher=The Times of Israel |date=2012-09-23 |accessdate=2017-02-19}}{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/rabbi-jason-miller/apples-jerusalem-problem_b_1923074.html |title=Apple's Jerusalem Problem |publisher=The Huffington Post |date=2012-12-03 |accessdate=2017-02-19}}{{cite web|author=Nathan JeffaySeptember 18, 2013 |url=http://forward.com/news/184099/kosher-smart-phone-arrives-as-ultra-orthodox-tech/ |title=Kosher Smart Phone Arrives as Ultra-Orthodox Tech Taboo Shifts - News – |publisher=Forward.com |date=2013-09-18 |accessdate=2017-02-19}}{{cite web|last=Ravidyesterday |first=Barak |url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/1.584241 |title=Haredi users of 'non-kosher' phones revealed through security loophole - News - Haaretz - Israel News |publisher=Haaretz.com |date=2014-04-07 |accessdate=2017-02-19}}{{cite web|url=http://www.israeltoday.co.il/NewsItem/tabid/178/nid/30063/Default.aspx |title=Rabbi: Never Marry a Man With an iPhone - Israel Today | Israel News |publisher=Israel Today |date= |accessdate=2017-02-19}} In 2015, he instructed [[United Hatzalah]] paramedics that in the event of a terrorist attack, they should not treat the terrorists before the victims, even if the terrorist is more seriously injured, and could even leave the terrorist to die.{{cite web|author=Contact Editor Hezki Baruch, 31/12/15 15:54 |url=http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/News.aspx/205765 |title=Rabbi Kanievsky instructs paramedics: Don't save terrorists |publisher=Israel National News |date= |accessdate=2017-02-19}}{{cite web|url=http://mondoweiss.net/2016/03/israeli-medics-are-leaving-wounded-palestinians-to-bleed-to-death/ |title=Israeli medics are leaving wounded Palestinians to bleed to death – Mondoweiss |publisher=Mondoweiss.net |date=2016-03-23 |accessdate=2017-02-19}} In 2016, Rav Chaim declared that medicinal cannabis was [[Chametz|kosher for Passover]].{{cite news|author=Elsa Vulliamy |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/marijuana-is-kosher-for-passover-leading-rabbi-rules-a6995761.html |title=Marijuana is kosher for Passover, leading rabbi rules |publisher=The Independent |date=2016-04-22 |accessdate=2017-02-13}} He ruled in 2017 that reporting instances of sexual child abuse to the police is consistent with [[halakha|Jewish law]].{{cite web|url=http://www.jpost.com/landedpages/printarticle.aspx?id=393109 |title=Leading haredi rabbi says sexual abuse should be reported to police |publisher=Jpost.com |date= |accessdate=2017-02-13}}{{cite web|author=ralph |url=http://matzav.com/video-rav-chaim-kanievsky-on-child-abuser-logically-he-should-be-reported-to-police |title=Video: Rav Chaim Kanievsky on Molester: "Logically, He Should Be Reported to Police" |publisher=Matzav.com |date=2015-02-26 |accessdate=2017-02-13}} Kanievsky has made several statements that indicate he feels the coming of the [[Moshiach|Messiah]] is imminent.{{cite web|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4032909,00.html |title=Ynetnews Jewish Scene - 'Arab unrest signals Messiah's coming' |publisher=Ynetnews.com |date= |accessdate=2017-02-13}}{{cite web|url=http://www.breakingisraelnews.com/47179/leading-israeli-rabbi-chaim-kanievsky-gives-new-clue-final-messianic-coming-jewish-world/#VXlipwdLuDCcq8Yf.97 |title=Leading Israeli Rabbi Kanievsky Gives New Clue to Final Messianic Coming - Israel News |publisher=Breakingisraelnews.com |date=2015-08-19 |accessdate=2017-02-13}}{{cite web|author=Title * |url=http://www.thecooljew.com/2014/07/rav-chaim-kanievsky-speaks-about-moshiach/ |title=Rav Chaim Kanievsky Speaks About Moshiach |publisher=TheCoolJew.com |date=2016-12-16 |accessdate=2017-02-13}} == Published works == Rav Chaim Kanievsky is the author of many works of [[halakha|Jewish law]], such as ''Derech Emunoh'' ("The Path of Faith"), on agricultural laws, ''Derech Chochmoh'' ("The Path of Wisdom"), on the laws of the Jewish temple rites, and ''Shoneh Halachos'' (a systematic presentation of the popular work ''[[Mishnah Berurah]]''). His [[halakhic]] rulings on prayer are recorded in ''Ishei Yisroel,'' and rulings pertaining to ''[[Shiluach haken]]'' are recorded in ''Shaleiach T'Shalach''. * ''Derech Emunoh'' on agricultural laws of [[Eretz Yisroel]].[http://hebrewbooks.org/49069 Vol. 1], [http://hebrewbooks.org/49070 Vol. 2], [http://hebrewbooks.org/49076 Vol. 3], [http://www.hebrewbooks.org/49076 Hashlama] * ''Derech Chochmoh'' on the laws of the [[Beis Hamikdash]].{{cite web|author=קניבסקי, שמריהו יוסף חיים, 1928 |url=http://hebrewbooks.org/pdfpager.aspx?req=51409&pgnum=1 |title=דרך חכמה - {{Christianity by country}} '''[[Christianity]]''' is a prevalent religion in '''[[Denmark]]'''. Aside from Lutheranism, there is a small [[Catholic Church|Catholic]] minority, as well as small Protestant denominations such as the [[Baptist Union of Denmark]] and the [[Reformed Synod of Denmark]].
Denmark is today a very secular country, but has a culture that is heavily influenced by Christianity.
== Lutheranism == {|class="wikitable infobox" style="width: 250px; margin-right: 0; text-align: center; margin:10px" |+ '''Church of Denmark''' |- ! year !! population !! members !! percentage |- |1984 ||5,113,500 || 4,684,060 ||91.6% |- |1990 ||5,135,409 ||4,584,450 ||89.3% |- |2000 ||5,330,500 ||4,536,422 ||85.1% |- |2005 ||5,413,600 ||4,498,703 ||83.3% |- |2007 ||5,447,100 ||4,499,343 ||82.6% |- |2008 ||5,475,791 ||4,494,589 ||82.1% |- |2009 ||5,511,451 ||4,492,121 ||81.5% |- |2010 ||5,534,738 ||4,479,214 ||80.9% |- |2011 ||5,560,628 ||4,469,109 ||80.4% |- |2012 ||5,580,516 ||4,454,466 ||79.8% |- |2013 ||5,602,628 ||4,430,643 ||79.1% |- |2014 ||5,627,235 ||4,413,825 ||78.4% |- |2015 ||5,659,715 ||4,400,754 ||77.8% |- |2016 ||5.707.251 ||4.387.571 ||76,9% |- |2017 ||5.748.769 ||4.361.518 ||75,9% |- ! colspan="4" style="text-align: left; font-weight: normal;" |<small>Statistical data: 1984,<ref>[http://www.dst.dk/pukora/epub/Nyt/2002/NR226.pdf Church membership 1984] Danmarks statistik {{da icon}}</ref> 1990–2017<ref>[http://www.km.dk/folkekirken/kirkestatistik/folkekirkens-medlemstal/ Church membership 1990–2017] Kirkeministeriet {{da}}</ref> Source: Kirkeministeriet</small> |} [[File:Sankt Knuds Kirke Odense.jpg|thumb|left|[[St. Canute's Cathedral]], Odense]] According to official statistics from January 2017, 75,9%<ref>[http://www.kyrkanstidning.se/utrikes/fler-lamnade-kyrkan-i-danmark Fler lämnade kyrkan i Danmark] 3.1.2013 Kyrkans tidning</ref><ref>[http://www.statistikbanken.dk/statbank5a/default.asp?w=1920 Statistics Denmark] Statistikbanken.dk</ref> of the population of Denmark are members of the [[Evangelical Lutheran]] [[Church of Denmark]] ({{lang|da|Den danske folkekirke}}), the country's state church since the [[Reformation in Denmark–Norway and Holstein]], and designated "the Danish people's church" by the 1848 [[Constitution of Denmark]].<ref>§ 4, "the Evangelical-Lutheran Church is the Danish people's church and is supported as such by the State" ("den evangelisk-lutherske kirke er den danske folkekirke og understøttes som sådan af staten")</ref>
This proportion is down by 0.9% as compared to the preceding year and 1.5% down compared to two years earlier. However, in similar fashion to the rest of Scandinavia, and also Britain, only a small minority (less than 5% of the total population) attends churches for Sunday services.<ref name="report 2009">{{cite web |url=https://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/irf/2009/127307.htm |title=Denmark – Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor |year=2009 |work=International Religious Freedom Report 2009 |publisher=U.S. Department of State |accessdate=23 August 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gallup.com/poll/13117/religion-europe-trust-filling-pews.aspx |title=Religion in Europe: Trust Not Filling the Pews |last=Manchin |first= Robert |date=21 September 2004 |work=Gallup Poll |publisher=[[The Gallup Organization]] |accessdate=23 August 2012}}</ref> In addition, the number of people leaving the Church has been on the rise: in 2012 21,118 Danes left the Church, an increase of 55% in comparison to 2011.<ref>[http://www.dst.dk/pukora/epub/Nyt/2013/NR103.pdf dst.dk, "Kraftig stigning i udmeldelser af folkekirken", February 28, 2013]</ref> Individuals automatically become members when baptized, as most people born in Denmark are at birth, and cannot leave of their own until they are 18 years old. Members are not informed of their membership or their ability to leave. Further, there are no standard formulas for leaving the church; one must personally contact the priest or office of one's parish.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.retsinformation.dk/forms/R0710.aspx?id=163780|title=Bekendtgørelse om stiftelse og ophør af medlemskab af folkekirken|website=retsinformation.dk}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.retsinformation.dk/forms/R0710.aspx?id=142350|title=Bekendtgørelse af lov om medlemskab af folkekirken, kirkelig betjening og sognebåndsløsning|website=retsinformation.dk}}</ref>
== Other Protestant groups == A small [[Baptist]] community has existed since the 1840s, and is represented by the [[Baptist Union of Denmark]]. The Union claimed 55 churches and 5,412 congregants in 2011.<ref>[http://www.bwanet.org/about-us2/statistics#e Statistics] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120627073219/http://www.bwanet.org/about-us2/statistics |date=2012-06-27 }}</ref>
[[Reformed churches|Reformed Protestantism]] is represented by four churches united in the [[Reformed Synod of Denmark]]. These are mainly ethnic congregations, including two [[Huguenot Church|Huguenot churches]] and a [[German Reformation|German Reformed]] church, founded in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries,<ref>[http://www.reformiert-online.net/adressen/detail.php?id=1070335&lg=eng Den reformerte Meighed i Fredericia]</ref><ref name="reformiert-online.net">[http://www.reformiert-online.net/adressen/detail.php?id=1070334&lg=eng Deutsch-Reformierte Kirche zu Kopenhagen]</ref><ref>[http://www.reformiert-online.net/adressen/detail.php?id=1070333&lg=eng Eglise réformée française]</ref> as well as the Korean Reformed Church founded in 1989.<ref>[http://www.reformiert-online.net/adressen/detail.php?id=1070336&lg=eng Korean-Reformed Church in Denmark]</ref> The German Reformed church also includes some Dutch, Swiss, Hungarian and American members, as well as Danes.<ref name="reformiert-online.net"/> There is an Anglican church and fellowship in Copenhagen and smaller congregations of Anglicans and Episcopalians in many Danish cities.
A 2015 study estimates some 4,000 Christian believers from a Muslim background in the country, most of them belonging to some form of Protestantism.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Johnstone|first1=Patrick|last2=Miller|first2=Duane|title=Believers in Christ from a Muslim Background: A Global Census|journal=IJRR|date=2015|volume=11|page=14|url=https://www.academia.edu/16338087/Believers_in_Christ_from_a_Muslim_Background_A_Global_Census|accessdate=2 October 2016}}</ref>
== Catholic Church == {{Main|Catholic Church in Denmark}} [[File:SanktAnsgar01.jpg|thumb|[[St. Ansgar's Cathedral]], Copenhagen]]
After the [[Reformation in Denmark–Norway and Holstein|separation]] of the Church of Denmark from the Catholic Church in 1536, the Catholic Church remained illegal in the country for over three centuries. The Church was able to reestablish itself after the Constitution of 1849 granted religious freedom to the Kingdom. Currently the country is covered by the [[Diocese of Copenhagen (Roman Catholic)|Diocese of Copenhagen]] with 48 parishes in Denmark proper and two more in the Faeroe Islands and Greenland. There are nearly 40,000 Catholics in Denmark, though nearly a third are foreign born and others are born of foreign parents (for example, Denmark's [[Polish people|Polish]] community, of which the current [[Czeslaw Kozon|Bishop of Copenhagen]] is a member). Nevertheless, ethnic Danes are still the largest group among the Church's congregants.<ref>[http://www.katolsk.dk/1635/ The Catholic Church in Denmark]</ref>
== Eastern Orthodoxy == Adherents of [[Eastern Orthodox Christianity]] in Denmark are traditionally organized in accordance with patrimonial ecclesiastical jurisdictions. Eastern Orthodox Danes of Greek origin belong to the Metropolis of Sweden and Scandinavia, under the [[Ecumenical Patriarchate of Constantinople]]. Those of Russian origin are directly under the Patriarch of the [[Russian Orthodox Church]].<ref>[http://www.ortodoxy.dk/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=14&Itemid=74 Russian Orthodox Church in Denmark]</ref> Those of Serbian origin belong to the [[Serbian Orthodox Eparchy of Britain and Scandinavia]].<ref>[http://www.svetigeorgije.dk/dk/ Serbian Orthodox Church in Denmark]</ref> Those of Romanian origin belong to the Diocese of Northern Europe, of the [[Romanian Orthodox Church]].<ref>[http://www.episcopiascandinavia.se/episcopia/istoric// Romanian Orthodox Diocese of Northern Europe]</ref>
== Oriental Orthodoxy == Adherents of [[Oriental Orthodox Christianity]] in Denmark are also traditionally organized in accordance with their patrimonial ecclesiastical jurisdictions, each community having its own parishes and priests. Oriental Orthodox Danes of [[Armenians in Denmark|Armenian]] origin belong to the [[Armenian Apostolic Church]].<ref>[https://www.kristeligt-dagblad.dk/kirke-tro/den-armenske-kirke-godkendt Armenian Apostolic Church in Denmark]</ref> Those of Coptic origin belong to the [[Coptic Orthodox Church in Europe|Coptic Orthodox Diocese of Stockholm and Scandinavia]].<ref>[https://www.koptisk.dk/index_EN.html Coptic Orthodox Church in Denmark]</ref>
== Mormonism == [[File:Mormons visit a country carpenter.jpg|thumb|right|250px|"Mormons visit a country carpenter" (1856) by [[Christen Dalsgaard]], depicting a mid-19th century visit of a [[Mormon missionary]] to a Danish carpenter's workshop. The first Mormon missionaries arrived in Denmark in 1850.]]
[[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] (LDS Church) has been sending missionaries to Denmark since 14 June 1850.<ref>{{citation |url=http://newsroom.lds.org/country/denmark |title=Denmark |type=Press release |work=Newsroom |publisher=LDS Church |date=2 April 2011}}</ref><ref name="Kirkens begyndelse i Danmark">{{citation |url= http://www.mormon.dk/?mod=artikel&id=60 |title= Kirkens begyndelse i Danmark (Church beginnings in Denmark) |work= mormon.dk |language= Danish |publisher= [[LDS Church]] }}</ref> Most of the early converts emigrated to the United States. There are currently over 4,500 [[Mormons]] in Denmark.<ref name="Kirkens begyndelse i Danmark" /> There is a [[Temple (LDS Church)|LDS temple]] in Copenhagen, known as the [[Copenhagen Denmark Temple]].<ref>{{citation |url=http://lds.org/church/temples/copenhagen-denmark |title=Copenhagen Denmark Temple |website=LDS.org |publisher=LDS Church}}</ref>
==History== {{Main article|History of Christianity in Denmark}}
==See also== *[[Church of Denmark]] or ''Den Danske Folkekirke''. *[[Christianization of Scandinavia]]

{{Unreferenced|date=July 2012}} The '''Door of Prophecies''' or '''Gate of Prophecies''' is a large door inside the [[Syrian Monastery]], of [[Wadi El Natrun]] (Natron Valley) in Egypt, that features symbolic diagrams depicting the past and the future of the Christian faith through the eyes of Christian monks of the tenth century. Several centuries ago, that location was used mainly by Syrian monks, however today the monastery is used and preserved by [[Copt]]ic monks and the [[Coptic Orthodox Church of Alexandria|Coptic Church]], as both Churches have been in friendship and alliance since early Christianity. The Door of Prophecies dates to the beginning of the tenth century, around 913–914 AD, according to the [[Syriac language]] inscriptions on it, during the papacy of [[Pope Gabriel I of Alexandria]] (910–921). The panels on the large door divide and represent Christian epochs through time, [[Epoch (reference date)|epoch]]s preceding the time of its construction, the tenth century and also prophesizing and predicting future time periods. The door of prophecies is a screen of a main [[sanctuary]] inside the monastery. It consists of six vertical leaves (panels) and seven horizontal rows, three forming a valve on each side. Each one of the six leaves has seven panels of ebony magnificently inlaid with ivory, however, today some of the panels are not in their original condition. From top to bottom they represent seven epochs which are believed to cover the history of Christianity, its past and future, highlighting its golden age, periods of major changes, hardships, and persecution. The historical and spiritual interpretations of the panels are highly individual. The following are the seven epochs: {| class="wikitable" border="1" |- ! Epoch ! Image |- | '''First epoch''', represented by the '''first row'''.
In the centre, there are icons of Jesus Christ and the Holy Virgin. The other icons, on both sides, represent the strong relationship between the [[Coptic Orthodox Church of Alexandria]] and the [[Church of Antioch]], i.e. the Coptic and Syrian patriarchates. The Syrian Orthodox Church of the earliest centuries of Christianity followed the leadership of the [[Church of Antioch]]. The monastery where the Door of Prophecies is located was built by Syrian monks. On the left are icons of St. [[Mark the Evangelist]] and [[Pope Dioscorus I of Alexandria]], representing the Church of Alexandria. On the right are icons of St. [[Ignatius of Antioch]] and St. [[Severus of Antioch]], representing the Church of Antioch. The order from left to right is St. Dioscorus, St. Mark, Jesus Christ, the Holy Virgin, St. Severus, St. Ignatius. | [[Image:Prophecies Gate of The Syrian Monastery TopLeft.jpg|thumb|The '''first row''' represent the first epoch of Christianity.]] |- | '''Second epoch''', represented by the '''second row'''.
Rows of identical crosses intertwined surrounded with circle. They represent the first Christian era which is characterized by strong faith, unity of dogma and church, and the spread of Christianity despite the challenges of persecution. | [[Image:Prophecies Gate of The Syrian Monastery Top2.jpg|thumb|The '''second row''' of the second epoch shows identical crosses surrounded by circles to symbolize the spread of Christianity despite persecution.]] |- | '''Third epoch''', represented by the '''third row'''.
Larger encircled crosses. These represent the Christian era during Roman rule under [[Constantine I]], highly respected and favored by Christians when large Christian centers appeared around the world such as the [[Church of Alexandria]], [[Church of Antioch]], [[Greek Orthodox Church of Jerusalem|Church of Jerusalem]], [[Roman Catholic Church|Church of Rome]], and [[Church of Constantinople]]. | [[Image:Prophecies Gate of The Syrian Monastery Top3.jpg|thumb|The '''third row''' of the third epoch shows six larger crosses representing the six major Churches of the world.]] |- | '''Fourth epoch''', represented by the '''fourth row'''. Crosses surrounded with crescents, sybmolizing the spread of Islam in Egypt and around the Middle East, the cradle of Christianity. | [[Image:Prophecies Gate of The Syrian Monastery Top4.jpg|thumb|The '''fourth row''' of the fourth epoch shows crosses surrounded with adjoining crescents, to represent the spread of Islam.]] |- | '''Fifth epoch''', represented by the '''fifth row'''.
The swastikas depict the spread of Christianity to the Aryans or Western Europeans. The swastika is thought to be the oldest Aryan symbol and contrary to popular belief, was not invented by Adolf Hitler during the Third Reich. Hitler adopted the symbol, finding it applicable to his political campaign and philosophy concerning the unity of the Aryan race. For more information on the origins of the ancient symbol please visit here: [[Swastika]]. | [[Image:Prophecies Gate of The Syrian Monastery Top5.jpg|thumb|The '''fifth row''' of the fifth epoch shows swastikas to represent heresies and false doctrines.]] |- | '''Sixth epoch''', represented by the '''sixth row'''.
Small divided crosses in different forms represent the multitude and disorder of doctrines and beliefs. | [[Image:Prophecies Gate of The Syrian Monastery Bottom6.jpg|thumb|The '''sixth row''' of the sixth epoch shows small divided crosses representing a multitude of doctrines and beliefs.]] |- | '''Seventh epoch''', represented by the '''seventh row'''.
The last row hints at the End Times for Christians, in one cross with a radiating design, filling the whole panel predicting the unity of the Christian faith. | [[Image:Prophecies Gate of The Syrian Monastery Bottom7.jpg|thumb|The '''seventh row''' of the seventh epoch shows one cross with a radiating design, filling the whole panel predicting the unity of the Christian faith.]] |} ==External links== *[http://touregypt.net/featurestories/surian.htm The Monastery of the Syrians in Wadi Natrun] *[http://www.st-mary-alsourian.com/ The Syrian Monastery] {{coord missing|Egypt}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Door Of Prophecies}} [[Category:Christian monasteries in Egypt]] [[Category:Coptic Orthodox monasteries]] [[Category:Prophecy]] [[Category:Individual doors]]
