Patterson write that when the [[Shunzhi Emperor]] (r. 1644–1661) of the subsequent Qing dynasty invited the fifth Dalai Lama Lozang Gyatso to Beijing in 1652, Shunzhi treated the Dalai Lama as an independent sovereign of Tibet.<ref name="norbu 52">Norbu, ''China's Tibet Policy'', 52.</ref><ref name="patterson 89">Patterson, "China and Tibet: Background to the Revolt", 89.</ref> Patterson writes that this was an effort of Shunzhi to secure an alliance with Tibet that would ultimately lead to the establishment of Manchu rule over Mongolia.<ref name="patterson 89" /> In this meeting with the Qing emperor, Goldstein asserts that the Dalai Lama was not someone to be trifled with due to his alliance with Mongol tribes, some of which were declared enemies of the Qing.<ref name="goldstein 10">Goldstein, ''The Snow Lion and the Dragon'', 10.</ref> Van Praag states that Tibet and the Dalai Lama's power was recognized by the "Manchu Emperor, the Mongolian Khans and Princes, and the rulers of [[Ladakh]], Nepal, [[India]], [[Bhutan]], and [[Sikkim]]."<ref name="van praag 11" />
When the [[Dzungar people|Dzungar]] Mongols attempted to spread their territory from what is now [[Xinjiang]] into Tibet, the [[Kangxi Emperor]] (r. 1661–1722) responded to Tibetan pleas for aid with [[Chinese expedition to Tibet (1720)|his own expedition to Tibet]], occupying Lhasa in 1720.<ref name="ebrey 227">Ebrey, ''Cambridge Illustrated History of China'', 227.</ref><ref name="kolb 368">Albert Kolb, ''East Asia: China, Japan, Korea, Vietnam: Geography of a Cultural Region'', trans. C.A.M. Sym (New York: Routledge, 1971), 368.</ref> By 1751, during the reign of the [[Qianlong Emperor]] (r. 1735–1796), a protectorate and permanent Qing dynasty garrison was established in Tibet.<ref name="ebrey 227" /><ref name="kolb 368" /> As of 1751, Albert Kolb writes that "Chinese claims to suzerainty over Tibet date from this time."<ref name="kolb 368" />
{{clear}}

page.title: The Parting of Lot and Abraham (Santa Maria Maggiore)

revision.comment: Added more categories.
revision.text:
[[Image:LotAndAberham.jpg|thumb|''The Parting of Lot and Abraham'' mosaic from Santa Maria Maggiore]]
'''''The Parting of Lot and Abraham''''' is one in a series of [[mosaic]] scenes, probably dating to the 430s, that decorate the nave wall of [[Santa Maria Maggiore]], one of the most prominent [[basilica]]n churches in [[Rome]]. The mosaic shows the story in the biblical [[Book of Genesis]] of the parting of [[Abraham]] from his nephew, [[Lot (Bible)|Lot]], as they choose opposing paths. Abraham (on the left) with [[Isaac]] and the rest of his family, chooses the road to [[Canaan]], as God intends him to, and Lot chooses to take his followers to [[Sodom and Gomorrah|Sodom]].<ref>Kleiner, Fred S. Gardner's Art Through the Ages : A Global History. 13th ed. Belmont: Wadsworth, 2008.</ref>
The work is a [[tessera]] mosaic, tessera describing the material making up the surface of the work. Most tessera works during this time would be made up of small pieces of limestone or marble, cut to shape, and arranged by the artist.<ref>"tessera." Encyclopædia Britannica. 2009. Encyclopædia Britannica Online. 03 Feb. 2009 <http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/588629/tessera>.</ref> The artist uses several conventions of the time. The grouping of the characters is varied, meant to create the illusion of space. This "shorthand" way of depicting a crowd is sometimes called a "head cluster". There is a hieratic abandonment of consistent and realistic proportions and scale, allowing the artist to put emphasis on the characters of his choosing using attributes like size. The main characters we are intended to focus on are made extremely clear through this method, and the picture itself becomes less illustrative and more symbolic. Eventually this style comes to a refined maturity during the Middle Ages. The move towards completely two-dimensional representative images has already started, and although this mosaic implements the use of lights and darks, with shadows corresponding to the figures, there is a good indication as to what direction religious art is heading.<ref>Kleiner, Fred S. Gardner's Art Through the Ages : A Global History. 13th ed. Belmont: Wadsworth, 2008.</ref>

'''William D. McCrackan''' (1864-1923) was an American journalist and author of books on history and travel. In 1900, he converted to [[Christian Science]] and became a Christian Science practitioner, teacher and lecturer.
== Life == McCrackan was born in Munich, Germany. His great-grandfather was Scottish and immigrated to New Haven, Connecticut around the time of the French and Indian War.<ref name="chron">[http://cambridge.dlconsulting.com/cgi-bin/cambridge?a=d&d=Chronicle19050318-01.2.94# "A Lecture On Christian Science"] ''The Cambridge Chronicle'' (March 18, 1905), p. 10. Retrieved June 22, 2013</ref> He graduated from [[St. Paul's School (Concord, New Hampshire)|St. Paul's School]] in [[Concord, New Hampshire]]<ref name="csj">[http://journal.christianscience.com/issues/1905/7/23-4/the-readers-of-the-mother-church "The Readers of The Mother Church"] ''Christian Science Journal'' (July 1905). Retrieved June 22, 2013 {{subscription required}}</ref> and Trinity College in [[Hartford, Connecticut|Hartford]] in 1885,<ref>[http://issuu.com/tcdigitalrepository/docs/1901_complete?e=3090139/3681928 1901 Trinity College yearbook] ''The Ivy'', p. 102. Retrieved June 22, 2013</ref> afterward traveling to Europe to continue his education at the [[Heidelberg University]] in Germany.<ref name="chron" /><ref name="rp3-193">[[Robert Peel (Christian Science)|Peel, Robert]], ''Mary Baker Eddy: The Years of Authority'' (1977), p. 193</ref> He lived in Europe for several years before returning to the United States.<ref>[[B. O. Flower|Flower, B. O.]], [https://archive.org/stream/arena08conggoog#page/n72/mode/2up "Reckless and Irresponsible Attacks on Christian Science"] ''The Arena'', Vol. XXXVII, January to June (1907). The Brandt Press, Trenton, N.J., U.S.A., p. 59. Retrieved June 22, 2013</ref>
He lectured, particularly in New York, and became known for his books on history and travel.<ref name="chron" /><ref name="csj" /> Politically progressive, he was well known in literary circles, was a member of the Authors' Club in [[New York City]]<ref>[https://newspaperarchive.com/new-york-times/1904-01-24/page-46 "Club News and Gossip"] ''The New York Times'' (January 24, 1904), p. 46. Retrieved June 22, 2013</ref> and was friends with [[Hamlin Garland]], [[Henry George]] and [[Lord Bryce]].<ref name="rp3-193" /> McCrackan was an opponent of the slogan "[[a land without a people for a people without a land]]". He said, "We used to read in our papers the slogan of Zionism, ‘to give back a people to a Land without a People,' while the truth was that Palestine was already well-peopled with a population which was rapidly increasing from natural causes."<ref>Muir, Diana. [http://www.meforum.org/1877/a-land-without-a-people-for-a-people-without "A Land without a People for a People without a Land"] Middle East Forum, republished from the ''Middle East Quarterly'' (Spring 2008). Retrieved June 15, 2013</ref>
McCrackan converted to Christian Science in 1900<ref name="Gottschalk">Gottschalk, Stephen. ''Rolling Away The Stone'' (2006) Indiana University Press. pp. 56-57.</ref> and became active with the church organization, first serving as Committee on Publication for the state of New York for three years.<ref name="chron" /> In that function, he wrote two articles for the ''[[North American Review]]'' addressing articles they had recently published by [[Mark Twain]], which had ridiculed Christian Science. He sent his articles to Twain, which Twain replied he had read "with admiration and with profit". McCrackan later called on Twain, and though they remained in disagreement regarding religion, they developed a cordial relationship.<ref>Peel, Robert (1977), pp. 202-205</ref><ref>[http://www.historyforsale.com/html/prodetails.asp?documentid=31406&start=44&page=43 "Samuel L. 'Mark Twain' Clemens - Autograph Letter Signed 01/14/1903" mentions McCrackan] History for Sale. Retrieved June 22, 2013</ref> The last time McCrackan met with Twain, [[Olivia Langdon Clemens|his wife]] was very ill and Twain, who wrote numerous articles critical of the religion, told McCrackan that he would gladly ask McCrackan to pray for her, except that his wife would rather die.<ref>Gottschalk, Stephen. (2006), p. 86.</ref>
McCrackan, a [[Christian Science practitioner]] and teacher, began lecturing on the religion in 1904 and was elected [[Reader (Christian Science Church)|First Reader]] of [[The Mother Church]] in 1905.<ref name="csj" /><ref name="css">[http://sentinel.christianscience.com/issues/2012/5/114-22/a-historical-perspective "A Historical Perspective"] ''Christian Science Sentinel'' (May 28, 2012). Retrieved June 22, 2013 {{subscription required}}</ref> He later became an associate editor of the ''[[Christian Science Sentinel]]''.<ref name="css" />
== Published work (partial list) == * [https://archive.org/stream/newenglandmagazi1896bost#page/n561/mode/2up "Andreas Hofer, The Hero of the Tirol"] ''New England Magazine'', (March 1896 - August 1896), pp 548–559 * [https://archive.org/details/riseofswissrepub00unse ''The Rise of the Swiss Republic''] [[Arena Publishing Company]] (1892) * ''The Fair Land Tyrol'' * ''The New Palestine'' * [https://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/006531951 ''Christian Science: Its discovery and development A.D. 1866''] (1915) * [https://archive.org/stream/spellofitalianla00mccriala#page/n11/mode/2up ''The Spell of the Italian Lakes''] (1918)

{{Japanese name|Yoshida}} [[File:Nijuunisha-chuushiki.JPG|250 px|thumb|A copy of the Nijūnisha Chūshiki by Yoshida Kanetomo]] {{nihongo|'''Yoshida Kanetomo'''|吉田兼倶|1435–1511}} was a [[Japan]]ese [[Shinto]] priest of the [[Sengoku period]]. He was a seminal figure in the evolution of a coherent descriptive and interpretive [[Model (abstract)|schema]] of Shinto ritual and [[mythology]].<ref name="ito">Itō Satoshi. [http://eos.kokugakuin.ac.jp/modules/xwords/entry.php?entryID=585 "Yoshida Kanetomo,"] ''Encyclopedia of Shinto.'' April 15, 2006.</ref>
==Career== Kanetomo progressed gradually through the ranks of the Imperial offices in the [[Jingi-kan]] (Department of Shinto Affairs), which was one of the Imperial bureaucracies which were set up under the [[ritsuryō]] system in the 8th century. Kanetomo's eventually became an {{nihongo|Imperial Chamberlain|侍従|jijū}}. Other positions he held at different times were {{nihongo|Senior Assistant Director of Divinities|神祇大輔|jingi taifu}} and {{nihongo|Vice Director of the Board of Censors|弾正台弼|danjōdai hitsu}}.<ref name="ito"/>
*'''1511''' (''[[Eishō (Muromachi period)|Eishō]] 8, 2nd month''): When Kanetomo died at the age of 77, his passing was considered a significant event in the chronicles of the Imperial [[history of Japan]].<ref name="titsingh368">Titsingh, Isaac. (1834) {{Google books|18oNAAAAIAAJ|''Annales des empereurs du japon,'' p. 368.|page=368}}; aka Ourabe no Kane tomo</ref>
==Yoshida Shinto== The early period Shinto school founded by Kanetomo was called ''Genpon-Sōgen Shinto'' ("Shinto of the Original Founder"),<ref name="ito"/> also known as Yuiitsu Shintō ("Only one Shintō").<ref>Scheid, Bernhard. (2001). ''Der eine und einzige Weg der Götter: Yoshida Kanetomo und die Erfindung des Shinto,'' p. 141.</ref> Prior to Kanetomo, the understanding and practice of Shinto was intermingled with Buddhism.<ref name="titsingh368"/> Sanetomo invested a lifetime in a process of disentangling what were thereafter construed as the two distinct entities.<ref name="ito"/>
===Inverted ''honji suijaku''=== {{Main|Honji suijaku}} The term ''[[honji suijaku]]'' expresses a Japanese [[Buddhism|Buddhist]] theory according to which a perceived Shinto ''[[kami]]'' is the manifestation of a Buddhist god.<ref>Satō Masato. [http://eos.kokugakuin.ac.jp/modules/xwords/entry.php?entryID=1356 "''Honji Suijaku Setsu'',"] ''Encyclopedia of Shinto.'' March 30, 2007; ''Basic Terms of Shinto'', [http://www2.kokugakuin.ac.jp/ijcc/wp/bts/bts_h.html#honji-suijaku_setsu "Honji Suijaku Setsu,"] 1997.</ref> This theory proposed and presumed that the resulting dual entity would necessarily have a fundamental Buddhist core, and that any Shinto aspect was secondary.<ref>Scheid, Bernhard. [http://www.univie.ac.at/rel_jap/gesch/honjisuijaku.htm "''Honji suijaku: Die Angleichung von Buddhas und Kami'';"] Breen, John and Mark Teuween. (2000). {{Google books|MADlfH002mAC|''Shinto in History: Ways of the Kami,'' p. 95.|page=95}}</ref>
In the late [[Kamakura period]], a counter-theory arose which also began with the notion of such dual entities; however, the counter-theorists construed that the ''kami'' side was primary and the Buddhist one was secondary. This came to be known as the ''Inverted honji suijaku ''.<ref>Breen, John and Mark Teuween. (2000). {{Google books|MADlfH002mAC|''Shinto in History: Ways of the Kami,'' p. 95.|page=95}}</ref>
Kanetomo was influenced by these ideas and brought them further. He proposed to set aside the conceptual theories of such entities.<ref>Shirayama, Yoshitarō. [http://eos.kokugakuin.ac.jp/modules/xwords/entry.php?entryID=1355 "''Han-Honji Suijaku Setsu'' ('Anti-Honjisuijaku thought')."] ''Encyclopedia of Shinto.'' March 30, 2007.</ref>
Up through the end of the [[Edo]] period, Kanetomo's followers and the [[Yoshida Shrine]] were granted the right to award ranks to all shrines and priests except for those associated with the Imperial family.<ref>Breen, John et al. (2000). {{Google books|MADlfH002mAC|''Shinto in History: Ways of the Kami,'' p. 176.|page=176}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Shinto sects and schools]] * [[Kunitokotachi]]

page.title: Zen Judaism: For You a Little Enlightenment

revision.text:
{{italic title}} '''''Zen Judaism: For You a Little Enlightenment''''' (Harmony Books, 2002) is a humor book by [[David M. Bader]], the author of ''Haikus for Jews: For You a Little Wisdom'' (1999) and ''[[Haiku U.: From Aristotle to Zola, Great Books in 17 Syllables]]'' (Gotham Books, 2004).
Widely circulated in e-mails and quoted on web pages, often without attribution,<ref>"For years, his [David M. Bader's] work has been all over the Internet without attribution." {{cite book |last=Novak |first=William |last2=Waldoks |first2=Moshe |date=2006 |title=The Big Book of Jewish Humor: 25th Anniversary |url= |location= |publisher=HarperCollins |page=xvii |isbn=978-0-06-113813-3 |accessdate= }}</ref><ref>[[William Novak]] and Moshe Waldoks, "All in the Timing," The Jewish Week, March 19, 2010 {{cite web |url=http://www.thejewishweek.com/special_sections/text_context/all_timing |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-12-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141226204756/http://www.thejewishweek.com/special_sections/text_context/all_timing |archivedate=2014-12-26 |df= }}</ref> this collection of [[Jew]]ish [[Zen]] combines Eastern wisdom and advice with Jewish kvetching.
The following are examples:
*The Journey of a thousand miles begins with a single "Oy." *There is no escaping karma. In a previous life, you never called, you never wrote, you never visited. And whose fault was that? *To know the Buddha is the highest attainment. Second highest is to go to the same doctor as the Buddha.
<ref>''From '''Zen Judaism: For You a Little Enlightenment''' (Harmony Books, 2002) [[David M. Bader]]''</ref>
